What information NEVER seems to be collected and announced by anybody concerns those who go to prison for some type of homicide. If collected, it would illustrate how many inmates and staff are killed and maimed by convicted killers, every year. The standard thought is to give them life without parole and they disappear off the scene. If it were only that easy. These killers get sent to prison, their lives are spared and they kill/maim again. Many, repeatedly. The medical and legal costs associated with these additional crimes is tremendous. What does a District Attorney do someone already serving a life without sentence for killing again?

It should be an ongoing annual FBI report of how many serious assaults and deaths are caused by people in prison for any type of homicide. It won't be, but I think the public needs to know the human cost (medical care until they or their inmate victims die) of keeping these inmates alive and living among others. Naturally, the staff garner no empathy from the public or politicians as they knew what they were getting into when they took the job. A Federal Correctional Officer in California was murdered by a killer just a couple of years ago.

Sad, but in the final analysis, it becomes cheaper to let them live and kill or maim (repeatedly) again. What a country.

In the simplest terms, the IPCC and SkS call for a continuous warming both over the last 17 years and 10+ months, and, thereafter, while Easterbrook called for an end to warming and possibly significant cooling after the PDO went cold and specifically after the AMO joined the PDO in their cold phases. This is the same position, essentially, as Tsonis and Swanson for NOAA and Mojib Latif and Eduardo Zorita for the IPCC, that these cycles all relate to the sun is obvious to anyone, unless they avert their eyes on purpose, like the former 'consensus' tried to do but failed.

As we have had no warming in any data set for years, 17 years 10+ months of no lower atmospheric warming and cooling since 2001, I take the view that Easterbrook (along with the other AGW believers mentioned) are correct, warming will remain in abeyance, and cooling, even substantial cooling, may occur for a great many years, at least until about 2030, long before then the major models confidence level will be retrograde.

We can argue each detail or error or we can say is it warming as projected, warming along the 400 year trend line, is there a pause, is there cooling, etc ...

The pause is agreed to by all but a tiny fringe, the lower atmosphere and all data sets are flat for years, the GISS data set has 5 and 10 year decadal averages cooling, as does the CRU, all severe weather indices are on the decline, Munich Re just shuttered its climate change operation.

More FUD. GHash is hovering around 30% right now; a drastic reduction from their exceedingly brief touching of 50%. You might do well to understand that a mining pool is a grouping of smaller entities that have simply typed a pool address into their mining software. If they so choose, these individuals can spend about 10 seconds typing a different pool address in and therefore pointing their hardware at another pool. That's exactly what 40% of GHash's prior users seem to have done in response to the perceived threat of 51% attack (I say "perceived", because, while it would indeed be bad, those who don't understand the technical details well, such as yourself, tend to dramatically overstate the ramifications of a 51%).

Now, that's not to say that the theoretical possibility of a non-economically-motivated 51% attack doesn't need to be addressed long-term (sidenote: the notion of a rational economically-motivated attack is absurd). A number of possible solutions are being discussed, and there's good consensus that a technical solution will be ultimately implemented. In the meantime, the major pools, including GHash, have publicly committed to staying under 39.99%.

In any event, this discussion is getting needlessly laborious, and it's fairly clear that one or more of the following are true:
1) You simply do not understand the technology and therefore arrive at bad conclusions.
2) You don't like bitcoin for some unstated reason and are trying to sway opinion.

All data sets show a long pause, even the GISS and hadCRU sets show 5 and 10 year decadal averages declining, though RSS is the longest. Longer views of the data show an entirely unremarkable 400 year warming with no acceleration in any index, even where warm-biasing has been extreme such as GISS has done, as have NOAA.

The IPCC's long view of carbon is not born out by any work I have ever seen, aside from its own internal elections, while 36 peer reviewed works disagree.

Nothing I have said here should be controversial and it is all verifiable and real. The planet has warmed since the LIA, some periods more than others, natural cycles, the mid 20th century warm cycle exceeding the last 20th century cycle, and since 2001 cooling, since 1996 no statistically significant warming in any data set, models at under the 2% confidence level (according to the worlds top IPCC modelers) and severe weather on the wane, even things like drought, cyclones, Australia, a heat wave also within known norms, no new continent wide record anywhere since 1976, about 40 years of unprecedented warming but no new heat record as to continents, on any continent, anywhere!

There has been some good coverage about sinkholes recently.* Like underground fires, they are part nature and part "nurture" (to misuse the word, meaning in this case human manipulation). Like older cities with buried infrastructure through the ages, our earth is honeycombed, particularly where the geology is porous, with natural and human-created remnants with various side effects. The one that got my attention was an old sulfuric acid dump from an ammo plant!

It certainly seems to me, having looked at the honeycombed nature of much of the far north in Siberia (and no doubt elsewhere) that as warming continues more and more methane will come to the surface. While scientists reassure us that there is much less methane (CH4) and it stays in the atmosphere for a shorter time (10 years compared to a thousand or so for CO2) I am not comforted at the overall picture of multiple methane sources, such as the waste from old and new mines, permafrost melt, decay, and animal feces.

*This is fascinating and contains a wide variety of information:
http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2013-03-20/science-sinkholes/transcript

Lousiana honeycombed with sinkholes and toxic emissions:
